title: week-radio-end-universe-humans-menu
story: All of them involve the destruction of everything, with only the bounce offering any hope for a sequel. Not that any of us will be around to see the climax, of course. Itrsquos a while away yet. I think Mack said it was likely to be ldquo to the power of  years in the future. Irsquom a bit vague on the maths, but thatrsquos a while away yet.Such are the incidental pleasures of radio. Itrsquos just on in the background and then suddenly you find yourself intrigued by something you had never thought of before. Such as what it might like to be a student scientist heckled by Stephen Hawking as Mack once was. Or thought she was. In fact, it was his voice box maling.On Monday night I was in the car listening to On the Menu on Radio  where Adam Hart was talking about mankind and the animals that, from time to time, eat humans. Lions and tigers and wolves, oh my. It was a fascinating , at times, horrying programme ndash one tiger watched his potential dinner for a week, taking note of behaviour patterns. Turns out going for a toilet break outside at four in the morning every night is not recommended in some parts of the world.Trophy hunting and human destruction of habitats both got a mention in a programme that was attuned to the social and environmental issues involved. And yet it was hard not to want to hear the next gruesome detail.Wersquove always been grub, it seems. The earliest humans were on the menu of, among other things, sabre tooth cats and hyenas larger than lions. Your best chance of escape back then  Climb a tree. So thatrsquos where the idea of tree houses came from.

title: Opinion  Rosemary Goring  Why we are all going mad for the joys of gardening
story: In recent months, it seems our village has been bang on trend as ever. Across the UK, as headlines foretold the devastation lockdown would wreak on this seasonal trade ndash footage of acres of wilting plants was grim ndash cannier businesses immediately shted to online and telephone orders. And, as recent figures show, people responded enthusiastically. During that period, Britons spent around pound. billion on garden plants, materials and tools. Contrary to the stereotypical picture of a Mr McGregor retiree, footering around in his potting shed, it was millennials who spent most. Their investment was double that of the rest of us, with the - age group spending an average pound per person, compared with pound among others.Some of that might be explained by the urgent need for equipment to turn a rectangle of grass into a more imaginative space for all the family to enjoy. Irsquom long past their age but still so new to gardening that I recall those early months as a ceaseless outlay on shears, secateurs, spades, forks, trowels, rakes, sieves... I could go on. Hence the need for a shed, which was soon festooned with tools dangling from hooks, propped against walls and stacked on shelves. Think of an Italian deli, with hams and salamis overhead, and floor to ceiling storage. Replace the delicious aroma of cheeses, coffee beans and truffles with potting compost, muddied buckets and oil to keep blades moving, and you get the picture.There are professional horticulturalists where I live who are well under , but thatrsquos probably not surprising. Those who choose to live in the country are already keen on the outdoors, whatever their vintage. Yet there is something of a renaissance occurring in this generation, as interest in their own plot is sparked into le, whether itrsquos an allotment, balcony, or back yard.In response to what you might call a growing trend, Alan Titchmarsh has said that he hopes more young folk will be encouraged to pick up their trowels and dig up drives, to help protect the planet. ldquoItrsquos not just about going on marches, he says. ldquoBeing practical is a hugely underrated resource and skill.Those who have unexpectedly found themselves with time to devote to their patch have probably realised how enjoyable it is too. Being in the fresh air, surrounded by birds, and perhaps with children larking around, has shown how much pleasure can be had in maintaining your part of the world. At this stage of le, competition for peoplersquos spare time is usually ferocious, with the demands of socialising, keeping fit and raising a family. In the past, unless you were actively emulating the Good Le, choosing to spend the weekend planting drills of potatoes or deadheading roses was borderline eccentric.Being forced to spend so much time at home has clearly made people reassess their outdoor space, and consider its potential. Making their plot child-friendly has been a priority for some. But for those who dread the thought of a football landing on tender seedlings and new blooms, there should be no conflict between serious cultivation and youngsters ndash quite the opposite. The earlier children encounter flowers and trees and the wildle they attract, the better for all our futures. And the sooner they recognise the need to treat living things with respect ndash although some trampling and breakage is almost inevitable ndash the more they will understand not just how nature works, but the ways in which we can support it.Irsquove lost count of the number of people who have said how much they have relished this aspect of lockdown. Having nowhere  to go has allowed them to concentrate on matters horticultural, and take time to make decisions or try experiments they otherwise could not have attempted. Having many more unfilled free hours has its upsides, as one neighbour has discovered. When the pandemic took hold she turned her greenhouse into a hotbed of tomatoes and her flowerbeds into a lettuce patchwork, and has been feasting on salads all summer. As have her friends.Inevitably, once the world opens up again, some recent converts will lose interest and the weeds will take revenge. Yet I have no doubt that many will already be hooked. The secret that no gardener ever mentions is that it is addictive. Each tiny success gives confidence to try something more adventurous. Mistakes are inevitable, but so are accidental triumphs. The thrill of discovering strawberries or nasturtiums thriving where before was a bed of nettles, is inspiring. The sight of bees and birds hovering for nectar, seeds and grubs is like preparing a banquet and watching as guests pile their plates high. To be honest, environmental reasons for sustainable, eco-friendly gardening are all but forgotten in the joy it brings. The reason why benches in most well-tended grounds go largely unused is because therersquos always something clamouring for attention. To sit sipping a GT while an unpruned shrub stares at you reproachfully, or a juicy stick of rhubarb cries out to be picked, is almost impossible.In my own limited experience, trying to keep on top of it all ndash and never coming remotely close ndash is part of what it is about. An expert recently told me that a garden will take all the time you give it, and then some. Yet the depths of winter is the time to put your feet up . The rest of the year is for helping the green things around you put down sturdy roots. As millennials can confirm, it has a very stabilising, calming effect on us too.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: fidelma-cook-truly-blessed-believe-know-thank
story: I have fast acting metastatic lung cancer. Already fragile, the chemotherapy more or less flatlined me with insupportable pain. In fact Irsquove just discovered that for a week it was touch and go whether Irsquod live or die.They may try one more chemo at  per cent or  and then decide to try further or not ndash either way wersquore talking months, and more than that I cannot say.I begged them to just let me die. And today my hair fell out in clumps.Itrsquos a bit late now but Irsquove finally learnt some lessons I should have accepted long ago and I pass on to you for what they are worth.Independence, solitude, pride in work and only work are all marvellous when fit and gregarious, travelling the world with a calm viewpoint.When older and shocked by illness ndash alone and fearful and worried sick about Ceacutesarrsquos future there is little glamour and excitement in living in the south of France alone unable to walk as muscles have atrophied after months in rehab.In fact I cannot live alone again. The French system will help me but not night-times and the truth is I need someone to live with me and speak comforting words in English and make me laugh in English.And I wish Irsquod told my son more often how much I loved him and how proud he made me instead of expecting him to know it. I wish I realised he loved me too in the same way and I hope he knows too the joy I get from seeing his love in his two small daughters.I wish Irsquod accepted the love offered from the odd, kind decent man instead of seeing it as a weakness ndash discovering too late itrsquos a strength beyond price when wrapped in strong arms as night falls.And I wish Irsquod told you all this as it slowly dawned on me as I wrote the bravura words I both meant and feared not. I wish, too, Irsquod admitted my loneliness and the stubbornness that drove me here and kept me here.But as many things in le all is understood just that little too late and anyway it was fun at the time, wasnrsquot it Were I still well Irsquod have no intention of leaving France but the last year has seen me long for walks in the rain, good non-French food, wind feathering the tree tops, cool weather not  plus heat and dust mired tiles.Itrsquos made me long for old friends, black taxis, carol singing in city streets, drives to proper pubs. Irsquove never ceased longing for MS food halls, fish, chips and mushy peas, roast beef and Yorkshire puddings. Strange how food, after so many years of dieting, fills my dreams. Or maybe not.Made me long for the mixed age range of friends we take for granted ndash not the segregated ages and sexes of rural France.Makes me long for home.Now, confession time. Pride brought me here and, laterally, pride kept me here.Pride, and lack of cash have kept me trapped ndash in beauty, yes, but trapped all the same.Never let pride be your downfall when enough is enough. Enjoy while you can and, despite all Irsquove said today, have no regretshellip.well, almost none.And laugh, always laugh ndash after the first few years the raucous laughter of Glasgow disappeared as did friends and I was left here with the Shires and the country folk. It was never enough but, thank God, yoursquove been there and Irsquove loved, yes, loved, you all.And you, God knows why as yoursquove shown these last weeks, have loved me. I have been truly blessed and believe me I know it.Your prayers, your thoughts, your confidences, have made me feel a far better person than I am.Ah dear, this is starting to read as my farewellhelliplet us pray not. There is always hope there is always a groundswell willing one onhellipyou, dearest friends are mine.So once morehellip.onwards and upwards

title: tv-preview-marks-get-set-eternal-race-life
story: ldquoEvery director Irsquove ever worked with only wished they could have had a car chase or action scene like that, the composer tells Planet Earth: a Celebration . He is referring, of course, to the famous baby iguana chase in Planet Earth II, as shown again in this compilation.To set the scene: marine iguana hatchlings are poking their heads out of the sand for the first time. Their mission is to get to the sea. It should be a short, simple scramble across the beach and rocks, but lying in wait for the newbies are racer snakes, superfast slitherers who regard baby iguanas the way some of us do white chocolate Magnums.We watch young lsquoun after young lsquoun make the dash. Itrsquos always the same. The little one edges out cautiously, sees nothing, and starts walking. Then the snakes appear from the rocks and all the viewer can do is shout ldquoRUN! Itrsquos carnage. Then we come to the contestant I like to call ldquoLucky. Even though you may have seen his dash countless times it is impossible not to cheer the little fella on. The iguana chase is one of eight classic scenes from Planet Earth II and Blue Planet II. The reason for the compilation, other than filling a gap in the schedules  ldquoTo lt the nationrsquos spirits during a time of crisis, says Sir David Attenborough in a new narration. There is a new score, too, courtesy of Zimmer and the rap artist and classically trained pianist Dave.Itrsquos all here, the bottlenose dolphins surfing ldquofor the sheer joy of it the shark v octopus fight a pack of lions trying to take down a giraffe flamingoes parading the whales and their hunting calls. As Attenborough says, ldquoIn times of crisis the natural world can be a source of both inspiration and escape. Perhaps because of this determination to cheer us up there has been a scaling back on scenes of violence and death .Spectacular, thrilling and magical ndash the kind of film that makes you wish you had given in to demands for a telly with a screen the size of a pool table. Dang that innate good taste.You have to hand it to Channel  when it comes to programme titles. Take new show Lodgers for Codgers , which brings together young people who cannot get on the property ladder with elderly homeowners rattling around in big houses. Lodgers for codgers, see  A tad cheeky, but does the job.Serious points are made by way of introduction. Did you know that four million over-s live alone, while five million young adults will never be able to afford their own home  Or that three million young adults still live with their parents ndash % more than  years ago The scene set, the producers settle down to generating some reality show froth. A ldquospeed dating session is organised where young and old can meet to seethey would like to try living together for a week.Marvell, , a poet from London, hits it off with retired teachers John and Lynne from Glastonbury. Living with his mother and sister in a cramped flat, Marvell craves some space and peace.The episodersquos second pairing is between Sophie, , a fashion student from Solihull, and Eunice, an octogenarian living in Birmingham.You can tell immediately where the strains are going to show, and there is an element of trying too hard in some of the scenes. But that doesnrsquot mean it cannot be entertaining and a little bit enlightening at the same time ndash exactly what this kind of series should be.The cynicalwill want to stay for the end credits to find out how it all worked out.No sooner have you caught your breath after the first series of Harlotsthan the second one is beginning. The first couple of episodes, stuffed with bare buttocks, cackling women and off-colour jokes, were but a mere shop window display to tempt the viewer in. After that, Harlots became savage and bleak, the characters developed in surprising ways, and the stories took root.The depiction of a rotten and corrupt London where women were there for the using and abusing makes for some shocking scenes. But the camaraderie among the gals ndash those that donrsquot hate each other, like rival madams Margaret Wells and Lydia Quigleyndash is heartening.Finally, hands hovering over imaginary buzzers please as Darwin College Cambridge take on the University of St Andrews in University Challenge . No Googling at the back, now.

title: TV REVIEW   Location  Location  Location  20 Years and Counting  Has it been a show too long
story: Channel  All  ***I KNOW what you are thinking. Can I really have spent  years of my le watching two posh sorts show punters round mid-priced houses with scope for an extension round the back ldquoHave we changed in  years  Phil Spencer asked his oppo, Kirstie Allsopp, at the start of this look back in languor show featuring the best bits of the Channel  property programme.ldquoHave you looked at your hair  shrieked Kirstie with all the JCB-in-a-china-shop delicacy for which she is known.Britainrsquos second most famous couple who are not a couplereally have been at this lark for a long time. Sometimes they have even found properties people go on to buy. Mostly, though, each episode is a lesson in home-hunting reality: what the buyer can afford versus what they want. Everything is a compromise, except for the cardinal rule set out in the title.On that, Kirstie had some shock news. ldquoI bought in the wrong area, she told Phil as they reminisced about their first flats . Kirstiersquos mum thought the neighbourhood was safe, but the transport links were rubbish and it was a long way from her friends. So you see, Kirstie has been there, done that, and got the corns from a twice daily slog to and from a distant Tube station to show for it.: Kirsties Keep Crafting review The pair raced through house hunts down the years, starting with their first, a search for a one bed flat in central-ish London. Kate, the buyer, had pound, to spend. Today that would probably get you a part-share in a parking space.A laddish Phil and a foxy Kirstie, all knee high boots, swinging hair and shades, strode the London streets like Julie Burchill and Tony Parsons. Two hip young gunslingers taking on the world. Her voice was softer, her manner less confident. Phil hasnrsquot changed a bit, apart from the receding forehead.The essential building blocks of the show have stayed the same, too. ldquoWe headed to a quiet bar to think things through, said Phil in that first show. Cue the call to estate agents to put in a cheeky offer well under the asking price. Then the tense wait.Before getting to that point there were tours round houses, Kirstie being up front and pushy, Phil adopting a more softly-softly approach. Kirstie hated it when Phil said, as he did often, ldquoItrsquos up to them. Kirstie wanted to give buyers the stats on the best time to start a family so they would stop dithering about the number of bedrooms needed.We did not learn much that was new as Ben and Laura, Jess and Sam, and Michelle and Philip, followed the original Kate into the snakes and ladders game that is buying a house. But then after  years we have probably taken in Kirstie and Philrsquos advice by osmosis. Who does not know by now to look beyond the dreaded woodchip, or the value of knocking through : Which house was crowned Scotlands Home of the Year What we did leave with was a sense that Kirstie and Pip, as she calls him, have done well out of Location, Location, Location. Through dedication, dedication, dedication they have transformed a modest idea for a property show into a successful double decade career with spin-offs including Love it or List It. Thatrsquos pretty good going in TV today.Itrsquos all about chemistry, too, with the pairrsquos genial brother and sister best pals bickering making whatever time they have on screen fly by.Herersquos to the next  years. Who knows, by then the location in question might be Mars.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: letters-figures-prove-union-doesnt-work-scotland
story: Although Scotland is the best-performing area of the UK outside London and the south-east, the vast inequalities in regional performance in the UK are the greatest in Europe and raises questions about the suitability of the current economic and political models.Almost % of the total GERS deficitis interest levied for the UKrsquos national debt, which, under international law, Scotland is not liable for post-independence. In addition, pound.bn is removed from Scotlands accounts for UK defence , plus pound.bn for other UK services home and abroad, all of which a Scottish government with dferent priorities could reduce.Many small European countries have matched the UKrsquos Covid financial response and last year Norwayrsquos government raised almost pound billion from oil and gas revenues compared to the pound million attributed to Scotland, which is a lasting testament to Westminsterrsquos mismanagement and over-generous tax allowances.Unless we take the opportunity to change things with self-government, Scotlandrsquos fiscal position will only get worse after Brexit as the UK, despite consistently failing to balance its books, faces a decade of austerity.Mary Thomas, Edinburgh EH.IT would appear that Jill Stephensonis content to sponge off the taxpayers of the southeast of England. What a shameful position for anyone to take, either in a personal capacity or as a Scot.Scotlands economy has suffered a succession of catastrophic impacts at the hands of a succession of right-wing ideologically-driven governments, starting with Margaret Thatchers scrapping of Scotlands industrial capacity in the s, through the financial disaster of  and culminating with Brexit in . The fact that oil from Scotlands territory subsidised the de-industrialisation of the s and then supported the expansion of the City of Londons financial sector only underlines the irony of the position held by Ms Stephenson.Scotland will have the freedom to grow its economy only when it is free of interference by Westminster. The next catastrophe, of course, is going to be Brexit. Scotlands population has expanded steadily since ,, but that growth will stall as soon as Westminster is able to deny the immigration we need here. Scotlands GDP is considerably smaller than near neighbours with similar populations such as Norway, Denmark, Ireland and Finland, the reason for that is that these small independent countries can tailor their economies to their needs, not the needs of the city of London and the South East of England.Scotland doesnt need nuclear submarines, aircraft carriersor global military reach, all of which cost a lot more than the pound. billion that Ms Stephenson claims, but we do need infrastructure, health care, education and above all people to grow our economy.The GERS figures may seem to be a godsend to people who think like Ms Stephenson, but all they really do is underline the structural failures and weakness of the United Kingdoms economy.John Jamieson, Ayr.IT is sad to say that some who would refer to themselves as Scots appear proud of the fact that under the current constitutional arrangements Scotland seems, at least on a superficial level, to be "subsidised" by the rest of the UK. Of course not only is this assessment distorted because Wales, Northern Ireland and the North of England are apparently more heavily dependent on the largesse of Londoners, but because only tax revenues directly attributable to Scotland are included in Scottish revenues raised while non-directly attributable expenditures, such as defence, are pro-rated by Westminster.Of course the deliberately conjured smoke and mirrors hide the slanted workings of the UK economy which leverages resources from outside of the south-east of England to maximise the financial growth of London. Scotland was effectively in surplus for most of the last four decades but not only was no oil wealth fund created for the benefit of future generations, Scotland did not even obtain close to a population proportion of the massive infrastructure spending in and around London, an economically debilitating relative predicament which is set to continue for the foreseeable future . The people of Scotland are just as capable as those of our southern neighbour, but we can only prosper in accordance with our collective talents when we can invest all our resources in our own country.Stan Grodynski, Longniddry.THE annual furore over the GERS figures is now in predictable full swing. No one has ever seriously uttered the popular grievance mantra of "too poor, too smallrsquo with regards to Scotland.But this isnrsquot  any more. Oil prices have plummeted. Covid- is still playing out, in ways that cant be predicted. The global economy is reeling and climate instability is increasing.How much would an independent Scotland borrow, how would the deficit be dealt withincreased taxes or a reduction in services, or both. Or neither  How would Scotland be a competitive place for business The SNP needs to start tackling the "known unknowns and "unknown unknowns" of Scottish independence with a rigorous hard factual honesty that it has yet to muster, lest we all vote for a st century version of the Darien Scheme at some point in the future.Surely the people of Scotland deserve better than the "Nah, itll be fine" attitude that the SNP have been peddling for six years now.David Bone, Girvan.YET again Ruth Marrtrots out the untruth that The Vow was forgotten by those who committed to it, so once again, it is necessary to refute that assertion.The Vow of September  was signed by Prime Minister David Cameron, Deputy PM Nick Clegg and Leader of the Opposition, Ed Miliband and promised three things and three things only. These were: statutory protection for existence of the Scottish Parliament new extra powers for that Parliament and the preservation of the Barnett Formula. Of these, the first two were enacted in the Scotland Act  . The Barnett Formula also remains intact.Likewise, Ms Marrs claim that a No vote would guarantee EU membership is a distortion of the truth. What was in fact said was that a Yes vote would be a vote to leave the EU at the same time as Scotland left the UKndash which was based on the unambiguous opinion of the EU Commission as provided to the Scottish Parliament.Again the question must asked:Scottish independence is such a good thing, why do nationalists need to tell so many lies to convice the rest of us of their case Peter A Russell, Glasgow G.NICOLA Sturgeon in her daily briefing todaysaid that the Scottish Government has used the UK-wide Covid- testing system "which allows us to deliver economies of scale, so it is the right approach to take". Need I say more Ian Watson, Pitlochry.Read more: Letters: GERS figures show why we cannot leave the UK

title: leadership-furlough-sticky-tape
story: The IndependentSean OrsquoGrady compared the First Ministerrsquos Covid briefings with Boris Johnsonrsquos performance in Westminster.ldquoHer professionalism is consummate and her work ethic prodigious, he said. ldquoEventhey were not, she doesnrsquot really need to do any more than turn up and do her daily ldquoIrsquom in charge schtick to draw the appropriate contrast with the clown down in Downing Street.ldquoWhere Johnson has long since tired of turning up to face the media, or understand how many families make a bubble, Sturgeon is the Duracell bunny of devolved administration.He said that after running through the daily stats, condolences and local lockdowns, she took some time to answer journalists questions lsquowith just a pinch of the impatience that conveys to the viewer that this very busy chief executive has indeed already carefully considered whatever point the journalist on the Zoom call might put to her.rsquoldquoShe does not ruffle that crash-helmet hairstyle she does not lapse into Latin she avoids lame gags she does not swallow her words, he added. ldquoShe looks ready to take the stage at the UN as the first prime minister of an independent Scotland.Johnsonrsquos performance has hardly moved on since his efforts in the Oxford Union Society, he said.ldquoScottish independence looks increasingly inevitable, and, able as she is, Sturgeon could never secure it without Johnsonrsquos own inadvertent contribution, he said. ldquoSo when it happens, you know who to blame.The Daily MailAlex Brummer said Britain had been placed firmly at the bottom of output tables for the G biggest economies in the second quarter of the year.ldquoThe UKrsquos performance is so much worse than that of the countryrsquos major competitors that it verges on embarrassment, at minus-. per cent against an average of minus-. per cent across all advanced economies, he said. ldquoIt is possible to come up with excuses for this dismal outcome. The UK lockdown came later than many competitors and the discipline of citizens and companies meant it was more watertight than imagined.He said there was a slight upsurge in June, and a bigger jump in July and August, with the eat out, help out scheme.ldquoClearly, there are sectors gasping for air, including traveland the service sector in moribund city centres, he said.ldquoThe extreme privilege of working from home contributes heavily to that problem and potentially is a huge drag on productivity.He said the housing market lsquocontinues to defy all expectations with transactions at a -year high last monthrsquo, and another optimitic sign is that Screwfix is to open  stores this year, including  in the UK.ldquoAdmittedly, some of this might look like clutching at straws and more Whitehall assistance may be required, he said. ldquoGermany is to spend an additional pound.billion to keep people in short-time work until well into . Sunak may yet have to revisit his furlough plan, which vanishes in October as a support for jobs.The ScotsmanJohn Blackwood, chief executive of the Scottish Association of Landlords, said landlords responded positively at the start of the pandemic to measures taken to house the homeless and protect tenants.ldquoRents were reduced or written off and homes provided for key workers and the homeless, he said. As things move on, he said the government is starting to err by applying the short-term thinking needed at the start of the pandemic to solving the longer-term problems caused by it.ldquoI was dismayed to hear the announcement by the First Minister that the Scottish Government intends to continue the extended notice period on evictions in the PRS for another six months to the end of March , he said. ldquoI believe this is only a sticking plaster, which when removed later, will make the underlying wound worse and harder to treat in the future.ldquoUnless the Scottish Government uses the powers of Holyrood to put money in the pockets of tenants so they can pay their rent, we will find ourselves back here in March  only with a greatly amplied problem.

title: salmond-inquiry-moves-bypass-scottish-governments-evidence-block
story: The cross-party group of MSPs said they were looking at whether they could obtain records ldquodirectly from the Scottish Courts after ministers cited legal privilege to withhold them.The move was driven by the ldquolack of documentation provided by the Scottish Government.The inquiry made the disclosure in newletters to the Governmentrsquos top law officer, the Lord Advocate James Wolffe QC, and its top official, Permanent Secretary Leslie Evans.It also said it wanted to recall Ms Evans, who gave evidence last week, for a second evidence session on September .Mr Wolffe has been asked to appear for the first time the same day.The inquiry is investigating how the Government botched an in-house probe into sexual misconduct claims against Mr Salmond in .The former First Minister overturned it in a judicial review by showing it had been unfair, unlawful and ldquotainted by apparent bias, leaving taxpayers with a pound, bill for his costs.Immediately after the collapse of the Governmentrsquos case in January , NicolaSturgeon told MSPs any future inquiry ldquowill be able to request whatever material they want, and I undertake today that we will provide whatever material they request.However her Government has since refused to hand over swathes of evidence related to the judicial review by asserting ldquolegal privilege and tried to stop witnesses from testying.In theletters to Ms Evans and Mr Wolffe, the inquiryrsquos SNP convener Linda Fabiani said MSPs remained ldquounclear on the dates and details of key Government decisions that influenced the direction of the [judicial] review.They therefore wanted to hold an ldquoexploratory session with Ms Evans, Mr Wolffe and other relevant officials to seethey would deliver a ldquodetailed account of the review process in oral evidence, as promised to the inquiry by Deputy First Minister John Swinney.ldquoHaving established what the Government is willing and able to share in initial oral evidence, the Committee can then consider further steps to obtain the evidence it requires to scrutinise the judicial review process in more detail later in its inquiry, she said.Ms Fabiani said the inquiry wanted to explore the extent to which legal privilege had been applied to the documents, the timing of Government decisions during the review, ldquothe Governmentrsquos approach to sharing information during the review, and the associated cost.She reminded Mr Wolffe and Ms Evans that the committee wanted a breakdown of the documents the Government claims it cannot supply as they belongto the court.She said: ldquoAs you are aware the Committee has also sought documents from Alex Salmond, and where these documents cannot be shared, for example due to an associated court order, the Committee has sought details of the type of documents that come into this category.ldquoThis includes documents provided to the judicial review by the Government.ldquoGiven the lack of documentation provided by the Scottish Government, the Committee is also now actively exploring whether specic documents not bound by the associated court order, can be accessed directly from the courtsrequired.

title: letters-emotion-not-logic-now-driving-nations-political-agenda
story: We have entered a looking-glass world where no matter how poor Scotland would be after separation ndash with no currency, no currency reserves, no central bank, a hugely negative rating on the money markets, a massive deficit, severe cuts in public expenditure, in pensions, and in salaries of public sector workers, the privatisation of state assets, large tax increases, and supervision by the IMF ndash supporters of independence are now ignoring reality.We have moved from logic to emotion as the driver of political action.William Loneskie, Lauder.EVERY year, Unionists gleefully seize on the GERS figures as "proof" that Scotland is an economic basket case. Unfortunately, the same GERS figures also show that all regions of England are likewise economic failures ndash the regions containing Birmingham, Leeds, Manchester, Bristol are all "basket cases" all of them even worse than Scotland, according to the stats. Indeed, in the independent Republic of Ireland, part of the current debate on Irish reunication is that the Republic would have to take on the burden of the British-administered economic failure of Northern Ireland.Do Unionists seriously believe that all of the UK, outside of London and parts of the south-east of England, is reliant on a begging bowl and handouts Tom Johnston, Cumbernauld.LONDONERS must be very irritated by GERS reports of Scotlands finances. Imagine all those billions which could have been spent on Crossrail, the new main sewer system for London, the Thames barrier, the Victoria and Jubilee lines, the restoration of St. Pancras Station, or another runway for Heathrow. We might even have managed to squeeze a few hundred more cronies into the House of Lords.It is also about time that more tax breaks were made available for the hard-working money manipulators in the City. Instead of these necessary expenditures the government is subsidising some ungrateful provincials.Peter Dryburgh, Edinburgh EH.JUST for the record, please allow me to assure Ruth Marrthat I have no wish to "cling desperately" to anything regarding the statements she calls the ldquoonce in a generation anthem" which she will admit was first ldquosung" by the Scottish Government and Alex Salmond in the  Scotlandrsquos Future White Paper. I questionedwhether these particular statements amounted to verbal contracts, moral commitments or word bonds. However, instead of answering what I asked, even with a simple yes, no or donrsquot know, she has launched into criticisms of entirely dferent statements by entirely dferent people, so I remain none the wiser about her view on my questions. Perhaps someone  will answer what she has failed to do  Alan Fitzpatrick, Dunlop.YET another column from Ian McConnell to dampen any thoughts his readers may have of trying to feel mildly optimistic about any aspect of le in general Business, August .I dont think I can recollect any of his recent articles, whether about business in our current Covid situation or the impending Brexit scenarios, being other than gloomy and doomladen to the extent that after you finish reading as much of it as you can bear, you need to lie down in a darkened room to await the arrival of the four horsemen.It is certainly true enough though that you would never get Mr McConnell confused with a ray of sunshine.James Martin, Bearsden.ALL the current turmoil in Belarus with protests against the authoritarian leader, Alexander Lukashenko , has reminded me of a statement made in  by Niall Ferguson, the historian. He said that Scotland was "the Belarus of the west ndash a small, sparsely populated appendage of England". Given what has been happening in Belarus in recent weeks and the fact that polls, since the beginning of the coronavirus pandemic, have been showing a majority in favour of independence for Scotland, one wonders whether or not Mr Ferguson has seen cause to revise his earlier statement.Ian W Thomson, Lenzie.IN , a Russian died by mercury poisoning in a London hospital. Two years ago Russians citizens were almost killed in Salisbury by nerve gas at the hands of two Russian agents. It is almost certain that Russia interfered with the American election that let Donald Trump into power. Russia also, it is claimed, compromised the Scottish referendum on independence and the Brexit election that saw us leavethe EU. A civil airliner was brought down by Russian missiles killing  people. Added to which Russian submarines patrol the English Channel while their bombers make regular sorties over the North Sea. Then there is the horrendous clamp down on democracy against the people of Hong Kong by what Boris Johnson calls "our Chinese friends".In all of this not a thing has been done by Westminster politicians other than derisory sanctions. Yet at the very hint of Scottish independence rising in popularity these same lacklustre politicians are instantly galvanised into becoming outraged zealots, even launching campaigns to stop the very idea of Scotland governing its own country. Just what on earth is it that causes such blatant rage  Frankly I believe that this anger has more to do with self-interest than concern. Losing a third of the British landmass is more than just anathema to Westminster it is an event that just must never be allowed to happen.Robert Gritton, Newmachar.Read more: Letters: Figures prove that the Union doesnrsquot work for Scotland

title: tom-gordon-richard-leonard-toast-time-find-replacement
story: For that is when Richard Leonard becomes Scottish Labourrsquos longest serving leader in opposition. Barring his removal agrave la Carlaw, he will have been in post  days.He overtook Johann Lamontrsquos thankless -day slog this week, and has now been in charge longer than Wendy Alexander and Kezia Dugdale combined, and almost six times as long as Jim lsquoThe Mayflyrsquo Murphy.Only Iain Grayrsquos -day peak remains to conquer, and when he gets to that pinnacle, imagine the view.When Mr Leonard became leader at the height of the Jeremy Corbyn fad, Scottish Labour had seven MPs after winning , votes and . per cent support in the  election.Under Mr Leonard - and Mr Corbyn of course - six of those MPs and , votes were lost just two years later, and the partyrsquos support fell to .% in Scotland.The same year, Scottish Labour also lost both its MEPs in the European election, when the party fell from second place to fth, as its vote sank from .% to just .%.The panorama of pain visible from Mr Leonardrsquos summit would also take in the imminent Holyrood election.In , his party won  MSPs with .% of the vote in constituencies and % on the list.The most recent YouGov poll suggests a quarter of those MSPs will be lost as Labourrsquos support falls to % in both seats and regions.:Watch: lsquoPolitically suicidalrsquo Richard Leonard left red-faced after horror FMQsThe same poll found most Scots barely know who Mr Leonard is. Asked to rate his performance, % said he was doing well, % badly and a whopping % were ldquodonrsquot know.To survive for so long without achievements, profile or prospects is, in its own small way, remarkable.But being Holyroodrsquos answer to moss wasnrsquot the objective.Mr Leonard is meant to be within striking distance of Bute House.After more than , days, itrsquos clear he never will be. He has had his chance and it hasnrsquot worked out. He is not a late bloomer but a dead bulb.Thatrsquos not to say hersquos a bad chap. He is manestly decent and sincere.At his best, he is one of the most commanding speakers at Holyrood.If he raises an injustice at FMQs, his solemn, unadorned phrases have an ability to silence MSPs and make ministers squirm in discomfort.However it is a patchy talent thatrsquos undone by the times he misfires horribly, as he did this week with a stale script and weak comebacks, and was shredded by Nicola Sturgeon.But his biggest problem is his failure to connect with the public. Too cosy talking shop within his own tribe - never get him started on trade union history - he hasnrsquot reached out widely enough to voters, hasnrsquot fought hard enough for their attention.Whatever the message, it needs the right messenger to be heard.As one party source told me more in sorrow than anger: ldquoHersquos making no impact whatsoever. Hersquos got no traction. Hersquos a lovely, intelligent and sharp guy, but I despair at times.Yet he carries on regardless, recently promising that he would lead Scottish Labour into the  election despite the third strike all around him know is inevitable. It will not be a campaign, but a resignation tour.While Ms Sturgeon will be askedshe intends to serve out a full term, few expect Mr Leonard to last the weekend after the votes are counted.:Anneliese Dodds warns Westminster Labour party wont decide Richard Leonards futureDetermination and a thick hide are necessary qualities in a leader, but they are not sufficient ones.Mr Leonardrsquos desire to carry on for the sake of the unions and the Left that elected him is understandable.But without Corbyn, he is a sidekick without a hero, a holdout for a ghost of a project rejected by the electorate. Ultimately it is selfish and lets down those counting on Labour in power, for without a Scottish revival Sir Keir Starmer will struggle to overcome Boris Johnsonrsquos  seat majority.Leaders heading for the exit cannot expect to interest voters, inspire activists or attract talent in the same way as leaders with a future.Jackson Carlaw had the same problem. He was not expected to stick around long after , and many of his key staff were already leaving when Tory HQ brought forward his departure date. Douglas Ross has a better chance of building a fresh team around him than Mr Carlaw ever did.I ask you, who is going to sign up for the last days of Richard Leonard So it falls to Sir Keir to spruce up Scottish Labour in the spring, offering a dferent anti-Tory vote to the SNP.It may not make much dference, but this early in his leadership he can afford to throw himself into the fray and take a few lumps, and therersquos no credit in ducking the fight.Thatrsquos the Prime Ministerrsquos modus operandi north of the border.All is not lost for Scottish Labour however. While Mr Leonard runs down the calendar, party HQ should work up a swt process to replace him, and interested MSPs can use the election to audition for the vacancy.Anas Sarwar is the battle-scarred favourite. He was wholly unprepared for the focus on his personal wealth that helped him lose to Mr Leonard. But he is tougher and cannier now. Monica Lennon may also apply.Although a coffin lid for Mr Leonard, the election could yet prove a shop window for his successor.Let the contest begin.

title: herald-view-transparency-matters-public-life
story: That is a principle that many governments find inconvenient. But the Scottish Government is currently not just in danger of being excessively secretive, but of making itself absurd through its refusal to provide the public with answers to basic questions.The question of when the First Minister first knew that people positive with coronavirus were being discharged into care homes is a matter of urgent public interest. It is not one that compromises the privacy of inidual patients or impinges on the Governmentrsquos ability to make the best decisions. Nor should it be one that requires her to obtain details from Public Health Scotland it is inconceivable that she does not know the answer. She is simply refusing to give it.The assumption must be that it is one that doesnrsquot show her and the Government in the best light. But the refusal to answer is worse than simply admitting as much. Scots are well aware that government is not infallible, and this Government in particular has been afforded a generous degree of latitude for its mistakes. In part, that may be due to the reasonable and realistic recognition of this fact that it presents in its rhetoric.That counts for nothing, however, when its responses ndash or refusals to respond ndash fail to correspond with those public statements. There has been an alarming pattern of behaviour on this front. To take just a few instances, there has been the Queen Elizabeth Hospital inquiry, the reluctance to publish minutes of ministerial meetings, delays to routine Freedom of Information requests, an attempt to sneak out an ICEA report critical of education policy, Audit Scotlandrsquos damning assessment of secrecy surrounding PFI projects, the disgraceful evasion over the role of government and public officials in the inquiry into Alex Salmond ndash after assurances that all such material would be forthcoming ndash and now the ludicrous claim that an effective reaction to the Covid emergency would be constrained by the answer to a simple question about when the Government knew what.All of these obfuscations give little reason for public confidence that an inquiry into coronavirus policy, when it finally comes, will uncover the full picture. The Government gives lip service to statements about how mistakes will undoubtedly have been made it makes glib pronouncements about how important it will be to identy them, and ensure that lessons are learnt so that they are not repeated.But the reality is that it goes to enormous s ndash and often, when the courts are involved, enormous cost to the public purse ndash to avoid answering such questions, far less admit its own failings. That is an unhealthy attitude, corrosive of public confidence and damaging to good governance.Whatrsquos more, given that the electorate is composed of grown-ups and, on current showings, far from censorious, it is a politically foolish and counterproductive one. There are relatively few legitimate reasons, generally to do with security concerns or momentous economic decisions likely to move markets, for government business to be conducted privately. Potential embarrassment to the SNP is not one.The expectation should be that frank disclosure is the norm it benefits the Government by making them seem like fair dealers, it improves policy decisions for the future and, above all, it is a reminder that the public has a right to know, and that politicians should be the peoplersquos servants, rather than the reverse.

title: seven-areas-scotland-curbed-house-sales-inquiries-decrease
story: The study by WeBuyAnyHome puts in perspective how each location has seen house sales inquiries change with the level of Covid- cases registered in the area.With only a % decrease in house sales demand compared to last year and most of the UK regions with an increase in house sales inquiries located in Scotland, the Scottish property market shows more hopeful figures than the rest of the Nation. .:Home in Largs: Flat in popular seaside town could be yours for poundKHere are the Scottish regions with an increase in house sale inquiries :Dundee and Shetland Isles are the Scottish locations most affected with an average decrease of -% and -% respectively.Here are theScottish regions with the highest decrease in house sale inquiries :: Where is the most expensive place to buy a house in Scotland Mark Irwin, Marketing Director at WeBuyAnyHome stated: "The property market, indeed the economy as a whole, has never seen anything like this before - any person making claims to know what will happen next and when, would likely be using guesswork as much as the layman would."However, interpreting these figures, we might expect the current bubbleto last until November, with economic struggles then causing a drop in values by approx."%, with it felt more acutely in lower value properties that donrsquot benefit from the stamp duty reduction, and as they tend to belong to lower paid workers who may be more susceptible to job losses and sadly being forced to sell."That is our current working assumption, but things are changing all the time."

title: scottish-football-fans-set-september-return-pilot-scheme-date-announced
story: The Scottish Government rejected a proposal from Celtic that would have seen a limited number of supporters attend their fixture with Motherwell this weekend.But the Joint Response Group have now confirmed that three games could be used as test events on Saturday, September .Rod Petrie, Joint Response Group Chair said: ldquoThis is a welcome and positive development for Scottish football, as the national sport, to build on the sporting pilot taking place at BT Murrayfield this evening.ldquoWe have already written to clubs to obtain their Return to Supporting plans specic to each stadium and will now follow-up with those clubs able to participate in the initial pilot on  September.If successful, these trial fixtureswould be part of a phasedof fans to stadia in the weeks following.TheJRG will liaise with Premiership clubs to finalise arrangements in the coming days.Neil Doncaster, SPFL Chief Executive said: ldquoClubs have worked tirelessly to ensure football couldsafely at the start of this month and news that fans will be allowed in, albeit in restricted numbers, within a matter of weeks is hugely encouraging.ldquoWe look forward to liaising with government to build on the sporting pilot at BT Murrayfield and to provide the necessary support to clubs to facilitate the eagerly awaitedof fans who - now more than ever before ndash are the leblood of our game."

title: economic-storm-blame-game
story: The Ross Clark remembers the Thursday nights when everyone gathered on their doorsteps to applaud the NHS workers risking their lives.ldquoThey were putting their own safety aside to work in close proximity with people who were desperately ill with the virus and were coughing it out in copious quantities, he said. ldquoCompared with the risks run by frontline nurses and doctors at the height of the epidemic in March and April the dangers faced by office workers now are miniscule.He asked why so many workers have not ed to the office, pointing out that, in London, just  per cent are back at work.ldquoYou have to wonder what has happened to the nationrsquos productivity given that millions of people used to an office environment suddenly work from home, away from the eyes of their bosses, he said. ldquoProductivity in many organisations has not exactly been impressive since staff started working from home. Just look at the backlog of passports and driving licences, the unanswered phone calls and the evident lack of joined-up thinking in many areas of government.He said that prior to Covid  many businesses had appreciated how having large numbers of people in the same industry working in close proximity helped to nurture and develop ideas.The reason many had not ed was pressure from unions, he added.ldquoYes, of course safety matters, and the virus is still there. But nothing in le is risk-free. Maybe we will work a bit more from home in future, but for now the economy needs workers toto the office. There is no reason why an overwhelming majority should not.The Daily MailSarah Davidson said the UK was facing an economic storm of toxic proportions.ldquoThe UK is already in a recession of historic magnitude. It could have been considerably worse without the support schemes rushed in by the Treasury as the country went into lockdown in March.She warned that the provisions put in place by the government were coming to an end and a ban on tenant evictions finishes on September .ldquoMany thousands of people will know within weeks whether they must find alternative accommodation by Easter next year, she said. ldquoFor some that will raise the prospect of homelessness. On October  furlough ends. The very same day, payment holidays on mortgages, loans, credit cards and car finance come to an abrupt end.If nothing is done, millions could end up unable to pay rents or mortgages. If furlough is extended, that would be like lsquohitting the snooze button,rsquo she said.Some solutions would include a benefit for those struggling to pay their mortgage, reinstate tax relief for landlords, a yearrsquos support for renters, a national housing bond and national infrastructure bonds.ldquoWar bonds appealed to the countryrsquos sense of pulling together, they were symbolic of the social effort it took to win the war, she said. ldquoWe need that spirit to be ingrained into our economy todaywe are to grow ourselves back to stability. The Treasury has proved this year it can be radical. Now is not the time to row back.Gaby Hinslf said the defining characteristic of the governmentrsquo is a cast-iron refusal to accept responsibility for any of the disasters.ldquoThe education secretary, Gavin Williamson, has lurched from disaster to entirely foreseeable disaster ever since schools closed in March, yet sails on regardless, even as the bodies of his civil servants pile up around him, she said. ldquoOn Tuesday it was Sally Collier, chief executive of the exam regulator, Ofqual, who quit amid continuing recriminations over this summerrsquos A-level and GCSE grading fiasco. On Wednesday, his departmentrsquos most senior civil servant, Jonathan Slater, was forced to walk the plank on the day news emerged of yet another last-minute handbrake turn on masks in schools.She said the real problem in shting the blame was that it didnrsquot solve the underlying problem of why the government seems to keep getting things wrong.ldquoIf it canrsquot confront its own mistakes honestly, then it has no hope of learning from them. And sooner or later, itrsquos going to run out of other people to blame.

title: st-kilda-postcards-discovered-norway-10-years-later
story: The letters were written to the Prince of Wales, National Trust for Scotland patron, and one of the last residents of the remote islands of St Kilda before they were evacuated.The last  people living on the archipelago,  miles west of the Outer Hebrides, were evacuated on August   after they voted to leave as their way of le was no longer sustainable.And  years ago, to mark the th anniversary of the evacuation National Trust for Scotlandarchaeologist Ian McHardy built a small waterproof boat based on the traditional St Kilda mailboats which islanders launched into the sea in the hope they would be picked up by passing ships or reach more populated places.The boat, which contained postcards to seven people including NTS patron Prince Charles and Norman John Gillies who left St Kilda aged five and died in , was launched into the sea from St Kilda on August , .Now, the letters have been found by in Norway after four children discovered the boat more than , miles away near their grandfather Geir Sorengrsquos boathouse at the beach on Andoya, the northernmost island in the Vesteralen archipelago off northern Norway.As they carried the boat home following its discovery in April this year, one of the children dropped it and the vessel burst open revealing the seven postcards, still in perfect condition, one of which asked the finder to send the cards on.Mr Soreng posted the cards to NTS in July and the organisation checked addresses and sent them on, with the cards finally reaching their destinations this month.In his letter to NTS, Mr Soreng said: ldquoMy four grandkids found a treasure at the beach on Andoya, north of Norway. It was a postboat in wood, sent from St Kilda in .ldquoEmil, nine, Ask, nine, Tiril, six, and Erling, four, were excited when they found a secret room in the boat, with seven cards. We had never heard of this fabulous island and are fascinated by the story.The card for Mr Gillies was sent to his son John Gillies, who said he was delighted to receive it.Mr Gillies, who lives in Aldham, Suffolk, said: ldquoItrsquos incredible really. For a postcard that has been in the water for  years itrsquos in remarkably good condition, you would think it was just sent yesterday by someone. It really was a surprise.ldquoMy dad died in  but he would have been really chuffed to have received it. For me to get it all these years later, itrsquos quite touching really.ldquoEven though he left when he was five he had very vivid memories of the island.Mr Gillies has a unique connection to the history of the mailboats.His fatherrsquos grandmotherrsquos brother was the -year-old schoolboy, Alexander Gillies Ferguson, who launched the  mailboat that is said to have started the St Kildan tradition.The uninhabited archipelago, home to nearly one million seabirds, has been in the care of the NTS since .Mr McHardy made the boat out of kiln-dried pine and the postcards were placed in a plastic bag in the hold which was sealed with silicon and painted shut.He said: ldquoI always suspected and hoped it would turn up eventually but I had no idea where and it was so long that I had kind of given up hope of it being found.ldquoI was just really excited to find out it had travelled all the way to the north of Norway.In his reply to the postcard, which was written by NTS Western Isles manager Susan Bain, the Prince of Wales said: ldquoI was delighted to receive your postcard and fascinated to hear about its decade-long journey to reach me, via the Arctic Circle no less.ldquoIn such a fast-moving world it is touching to know that the tradition of a simple mailboat from the remote island of St Kilda can safely travel so far.ldquoI have never forgotten my visit to this amazing archipelago in  and I so look forward to ing one day, not only to remind myself of its rugged beauty, but also its extraordinary history and breathtaking bird le.ldquoAs patron of the National Trust for Scotland, I am immensely grateful to all those who work to preserve our heritage through caring for special places like St Kilda.Ms Bain said: ldquoSometimes the mailboats worked very well as a means of communication and they got help within two weeks, but other times they took  years.It was nice the connection that people on a small remote island in Norway found the boat that had come from a small remote island in Scotland.

title: historic-pubs-final-round
story: The building, which has existed as a pub since , is being taken over by MB Jarvie Car Service next door who plan to turn it into offices.The decision to close the pub is the final death knell of a once thriving community which, before most of the area was demolished to make way for the construction of the M motorway, was filled with tenement lined streets and the bustling Gray Dunn Biscuit Factory.These days the Kinning Park region between the motorway and Paisley Road West is desolate, housing industrial complexes rather than families.The Stanley Bar continued to act as a meeting point for those who grew up in the area and became a popular pub for Celtic fans.But as from last night, its doors have closed.ldquoItrsquos the end of an era, said John Byrne, who runs the pub alongside we Elaine with other family members as co owners. ldquoWhen my we and I took over the daily running of the pub  years ago a regular said to us lsquoThis isnrsquot a pub ndash itrsquos a social clubrsquo. Itrsquos an institution. Itrsquos a sad, sad thing that itrsquos had to close.ldquoIt used to be absolutely jumping. Everyone from the Gray Dunn Biscuit Factory would drink in here. There were six flats above the pub alone, as well as all the other tenements. It was always a family pub. My we would feed all the regulars, buy them clothesthey needed it. Shersquod bring in pots of soup, mince and potatoes. There was never any trouble.The day before the pub closed, John McGarvey from Pollok was having one last drink with his elderly father Howard and his uncle Noel.Noel and Howard both grew up in Ireland and would meet in the pub with other members of the Irish community.ldquoWe lived in Eaglesham Street in Kinning Park, John said. ldquoWe have lots of happy memories of spending time in the Stanley Bar as a family. There was a close Irish community and my mum would sing traditional Irish music in the pub band. Pubs on Paisley Road West always changed their names but the Stanley Bar was always the Stanley Bar. Irsquove brought my dad and uncle here today for one last drink.Danny Rodgers from Govan is another child of the area. ldquoI was born on Stanley Street. My family grew up here. We moved to Cessnock just as the motorway was being built. Even though now therersquos no houses or communities, people still came back to the Stanley Bar and their sons and daughters would come because their parents drank here. For Celtic games and special occasions they would all come back.Another regular, Brian Devaney, who lives in Cessnock, chooses to drink in the Stanley Bar shybecause itrsquos the only Celtic pub in the area. ldquoWhen Celtic win big games we go outside in the street and do the huddle. It stops traffic.ldquoIrsquove drank in here for  years. My father drank in here. Itrsquos sad.Such are the strong memories associated with the Stanley Bar, those who have moved from the area continue to visit. Neil Hargan, who grew up on Stanley Street before moving to Blackpool, goes to the pub each time hersquos back in Glasgow. ldquoMy father worked in Gray Dunn Biscuit Factory. I have memories of the area and I know the regulars ndash itrsquos still the same people who were drinking there  years ago. There was a good laugh and patter and characters. I would walk in and it would be asI still lived there. Recently I went in and there was a man I knew sleeping on the chair beside me. He woke up and said lsquoAlright, Neillsy,rsquo asIrsquod never been away.ldquoIt was a good wee pub and there was no trouble in it. I am devastated it is closing.The area of Kinning Park between the Glasgow ndash Paisley railway line and Paisley Road West was one of the cityrsquos neighbourhoods lost to the construction of the M. Its sandstone tenements were demolished and residents shipped to other parts of the city, separating neighbours, friends and long held community ties.The closure of the Gray Dunn Biscuit Factory in  was another blow to the area, resulting in almost  staff being made redundant. The imposing building, which dominated the city skyline view from the M, was demolished in , adding to the desolation of the area. The former Our Lady and St Margaretrsquos Primary School opposite the factory site was saved due to its listed status and has now been converted into offices, while the adjoining former presbytery remains derelict.Called ldquothe last post by regulars, the Stanley Bar was the only remaining evidence of a once vibrant community.But with rising costs, dwindling regulars and Covid- making the pub more dficult to sustain,the Byrne family made the shydficult decision to give it up.ldquoIn the last two years around  regulars who came in every day for their half and half have died, John said. ldquoWe had two domino teams ndash four of the members have died. The price of beer has gone up, as well as electricity. Sky television ndash theyrsquore bullies. Twelve hundred pounds a month for a wee pub like this. Butyou donrsquot have it you donrsquot get the clientele. The last two years wersquove been struggling, last year was the worst, then lockdown finished us. And lockdown is going to come back again, we know it is.ldquoWe hoped we could sell it to business people in the community but they know itrsquos not making enough money. And the guy next door came to my brother with a great offer. Itrsquos a shame but what can we do  We tried everything.

title: football-added-pilot-events-scottish-sport-welcomes-back-fans
story: Provisional plans have been drawn up for three Scottish Premiership games to host fans in pilot events on September  ndash two days before the indicative date for spectators to be allowed toto sports stadiums in limited numbers.About  Edinburgh fans were granted access to Murrayfield for the Guinness PRO encounter, the first sports event to be played in front of a crowd in Scotland since lockdown in mid-March.### Keep up to date with the vital matchday information ahead of tonights derby at @BTMurrayfield.Stay safe and enjoy the game! #mdash Edinburgh RugbyAugust , The Scottish government had turned down Celticrsquos request to host a small crowd when Motherwell visit Parkhead on Sunday, stressing that the rugby test event could help provide lessons that would help football.But the football authoritiesrsquo Joint Response Group announced that sports minister Joe FitzPatrick had confirmed that up to three pilot events could take place in the Scottish Premiership on September .A statement added: ldquoIf successful, this would be part of a phasedof supporters to football stadia with incrementally increased numbers in the weeks following the initial pilot event date.ldquoThe JRG will be liaising with Premiership clubs and the Scottish government over the next week to finalise details.September  sees Rangers host Dundee United while Celtic travel to Dingwall to take on Ross County.Aberdeen host Kilmarnock, St Johnstone visit Motherwell, Livingston take on Hamilton in West Lothian and St Mirren face Hibernian in Paisley. Only home supporters are expected to be admitted.Scottish Football Association president Rod Petrie said: ldquoThis is a welcome and positive development for Scottish football, as the national sport, to build on the sporting pilot taking place at BT Murrayfield this evening.ldquoWe have already written to clubs to obtain theirto supporting plans specic to each stadium and will now follow up with those clubs able to participate in the initial pilot on  September.Sports fans back in Scottish stadium ndash Glasgow Warriors take early - lead over Edinburgh at Murrayfield pic ZylLFTOmdash Gavin McCaffertyAugust , Scottish Professional Football League chief executive Neil Doncaster added: ldquoClubs have worked tirelessly to ensure football couldsafely at the start of this month and news that fans will be allowed in, albeit in restricted numbers, within a matter of weeks is hugely encouraging.ldquoWe look forward to liaising with government to build on the sporting pilot at BT Murrayfield and to provide the necessary support to clubs to facilitate the eagerly awaitedof fans who ndash now more than ever before ndash are the leblood of our game.Fans were spread out in the east stand at Murrayfield and asked to wear face coverings, keep two metres apart and avoid face-to-face contact with anyone from outside their household.

title: lyra-belacquas-latest-adventure-nurse-ratcheds-early-years-10-best-tv-dramas-autumn
story: His Dark Materials, BBC One A smash hit when it aired last year, the BBCrsquos adaptation of Philip Pullmanrsquos HDM trilogy was always a dead cert for a second season given that series one only covered the events of the first book, Northern Lights. So expect the next eight-part instalment to follow Lyra Belacquaas she encounters the new worlds and new characters laid out in book two of the series, The Subtle Kne. Chief among her new helpmates is Will Parry , who featured in season one though the pair never actually met. Joining the cast are Simone Kirby as Dr Mary Malone and ndash screen legend klaxon, please ndash Terence Stamp. Finally, a note to Fleabag fans: Phoebe Waller-Bridge voices the daemon of the character played by Andrew lsquoHot Priestrsquo Scott.Two Weeks To Live, Sky One Game Of Thrones star Maisie Williams joins Fleabagrsquos Sian Clford in a black comedy about a mother and daughter with some very unusual skillsets. Kim Noakescan skin a deer to make a sleeping bag and strip a semi-automatic pistol in six seconds flat thanks to a letime of training by survivalist mother Tina . But when Kim sets out to try to join the real world and act like a normal -year-old things donrsquot go quite according to plan. Therersquos also the small matter of a dead father and a murder to avenge.Roadkill, BBC One Although this four-part political thriller stars Hugh Laurie the bigger name is probably its creator: celebrated dramatist and screenwriter David Hare, whose le Carreacute-esque disdain for the Establishment and its many grubby compromises will doubtless be given free rein in this tale of a conscience-free Tory politician ruthlessly cutting a path to the top job even as private scandal snaps at his heels. Hard to imagine who inspired the character of Peter Laurence, though one of Lauriersquos fellow Old Etonians does spring to mind. Roadkill also benefits from an exemplary supporting cast which includes Helen McCrory, Saskia Reeves, Patricia Hodge, Borgenrsquos Sidse Babett Knudsen and Sarah Greene.Ratched, Netflix From writing team Ian Brennan and Ryan Murphy, whose credits include everything from Glee to anthology series American Horror Story, comes this suspenseful psychological drama set in s Calornia. Mildred Ratchedis a psychiatric nurse who lands a job at a shadowy clinic where certain shadowy experiments are being conducted. Andher name sounds eerily familiar, itrsquos because this is an origins story of sorts: Mildred is better-known in cinematic history as Nurse Ratched, Jack Nicholsonrsquos vicious antagonist in the celebrated film version of Ken Keseyrsquos  novel One Flew Over The Cuckoorsquos Nest. A woman whose bedside manner leaves a little to be desired, in other words.The Sister, ITV Written by Neil Cross, the creator of Luther, and starring Russell Tovey The Sister airs as part of whatrsquos shaping up to be a pretty muscular autumn drama schedule from ITV. Tovey plays Nathan, an inoffensive family man whose le is turned upside down one night with the arrival of an old friend ndash Bob , who has some news for Nathan that he really doesnrsquot want to hear involving a shared incident in the menrsquos past . On top of that, Nathan has some fresher secrets of his own that he wants to keep out of the light. Based on Crossrsquos own novel, Burial, the four-part thriller also features Amrita Acharia.Away, Netflix Hilary Swank stars as astronaut Emma Green whorsquos preparing to lead a mission to Mars ndash and say goodbye to NASA engineer husband Matt and -year-old daughter Lex, played by Josh Charles and Talitha Bateman respectively. Relatively short by Netflix standards ndash a mere  one hour episodes ndash it also features actors Mark Ivanir, Ato Essandoh, Ray Panthaki, Vivian Wu and Monique Curnen as her League of Nations crew-mates.Des, ITV David Tennant dons a pair of creepy glasses to play Fraserburgh-born serial killer Dennis Nilsen in this true-crime drama written by Luke Neal and based on the book Killing For Company by Brian Masters. A civil servant living in London when he committed the first of the  murders he eventually confessed to when he was arrested in , Nilsenrsquos story is told from three points of view: that of Nilsen, of Mastersand of investigating detective Peter Jay .Singapore Grip, ITV Based on JG Farrellrsquos satirical  novel The Singapore Grip and adapted by Oscar-winning playwright and screenwriter Christopher Hampton, this looks like being the heavy hitter in ITVrsquos Autumn schedule. Set in Singapore on the eve of the Japanese invasion in  it follows the ups and downs of young Matthew Webb , whose ailing fatheris in business with ruthless rubber merchant Walter Blackett , who in turn wants to marry Matthew off to his daughter Joan . Itrsquos all going more or less to plan until Matthew meets Chinese refugee Vera . The title, by the way, refers to a sexual technique .Moscow Noir, Channel  All  This stylish Swedish thriller screens as part of the Walter Presents strand of top-notch Euro drama and stars Adam Paringlsson as a young investment banker in Moscow in , when the Russian capital was even wilder and more lawless than it is now. One for fans of McMafia and all those Scandi Noir dramas that BBC Fourhave made their own ndash talking of which, Paringlsson can also be seen playing the young Inspector Wallander in Young Wallander, Netflixrsquos lsquoorigins storyrsquo re-boot, which start on September .The Third Day, Sky Atlantic If you loved Channel rsquos weirdo conspiracy thriller Utopiathen yoursquoll adore this new six-part series from its creator, Dennis Kelly, served up in two distinct halves titled Summer and Winter. The first stars Jude Law as a man who arrives on a mysterious island somewhere off the coast of the UK only to find that the islanders have some strange ideas about how to preserve their traditions. The second story, unconnected apart from the fact that it takes place on the same island, stars Naomie Harris as a woman who arrives with questions for which she wants answers. Will she get them  If itrsquos anything like Utopia, the answer is sort of, but probably not.

story: coronavirusChange of opening hours at OIC receptionAugust ,  at : am vw, px"  A temporary change to the opening hours of the OIC’s reception desk is to be put in place tomorrow, Monday.Due to operational issues as a result of COVID-,  the switchboard and reception desk will now require to be closed to the public between -pm, Monday to Friday.To compensate for the closure during the lunchtime period, the council will open the reception each day until pm rather than pm.  Emergency contact numbers will be available on the recorded message via   and on  www.orkney.gov.ukThe revised opening hours will be as follows:However, folk are asked to only attend in person for essential business and to continue, whenever possible, to use other methods of contact such as online   via www.orkney.gov.uk MyOrkney, by email customerservice@orkney.gov.uk or by phone .An OIC spokeswoman said: #Additional safety measures remain in place and we would ask that anyone experiencing symptoms of COVID-, or anyone who has been in contact with a person infected with the virus does not enter the building.#Customers who need to see an officer are asked to make an appointment ahead of the visit. story: A project to create a virtual experience and improve accessibility on the St Magnus Way has won a £, award from the Calor Rural Community Fund.The prize is a share of an £, fund designed to improve local le in communities that are not connected to the mains gas grid.A six-week crowdfunding campaign to create a virtual way for pilgrims unable to walk the, at times, challenging route and improve accessibility on the path itself raised £,.The St Magnus Way is a -mile pilgrimage route through Mainland Orkney, inspired by the le and death of Magnus, Orkney’s patron saint.The route begins in Egilsay and covers Evie, Birsay, Dounby, Finstown, Orphir, before ending at the St Magnus Cathedral in Kirkwall.Alasdair Flett, volunteer at Orkney Pilgrimage, said: “We want to thank the Calor Rural Community fund, as winning one of the £, grants allows us to explore a full range of options in developing a lasting and valuable resource for St Magnus Way.“We will be looking into using aerial drone footage, -degree imagery and our rich library of pre-existing resources to build a digital experience that captures the essence of the pilgrimage for those who cannot currently walk the way due to barriers of distance and accessibility.”The money will also allow new gates to be added to the walking route and the path widened to allow for larger amounts of walkers and hikers.Andy Parker, head of strategy and corporate affairs at Calor, said: “We’ve been absolutely blown away by the response we’ve had this year. Over  community initiatives entered and the standards were incredibly high with some fantastic causes coming through.#It’s great to see how passionate these rural communities are and how each of their projects will make such a dference for all those living in the local area.“St Magnus Way’s development and repair is a great initiative and we very much look forward to seeing this stunning country walk become even more accessible to the public in Orkney.”Each entry was judged by four impartial judges who had the extremely dficult task of choosing this year’s winners.They based their decision on the potential impact the project had on the local community, its sustainability once launched, the originality of the project and the projects submission itself.There were three levels of funding available:  £, grants, six £, grants and five £, grants.For further information on the Calor Rural Community Fund and to view the full list of winners, please visit: communityfund.calor leaderboards winners-copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: local livestock association enters in to new partnership
story: Orkney Livestock Associationhave signed up to partner with the Moredun scientic institute to give their members access to research outputs, knowledge, skills and expertise generated by the Organisation.OLA is a farmer-led organisation aimed at improving the health of Orkney’s cattle herds.  The scheme was officially launched in February  with a programme to eradicate BVD and a Johne’s eradication scheme followed in November . The new partnership will allow OLA#s members access to Moredun’s members area with a wealth of livestock health information, including the full range of technical news sheets, and will also promote working together on joint events and initiatives.The work of the Moredun scientic institute have made a major impact both in the UK and globally, due in a large part to the unique relationship it has had has with the farming community and the emphasis the organisation puts on effective knowledge exchange with livestock producers.Retired local vet Willie Stewart, who is the chairman of Moredun’s North of Scotland Regional Advisors Board said:“The Moredun Research Institute is a world leader in the development of livestock vaccines, animal disease tests and control plans. I believe that OLA representing the cattle industry in Orkney can have a strong association with Moredun in the future.#Beth Wells, from Moredun, said “Through meetings we have been fortunate to meet many of Orkney’s livestock farmers, who are well known for their high quality beef production and we are delighted to be developing a closer working collaboration with OLA, which will be of huge benefit to both of our organisations.”OLA is a sub-group of HiHealth Herdcare which is a national cattle health scheme. Karen Johnston, from OLA, said: “We are delighted and very honoured to give our members the opportunity to benefit from expert information and support from such a prestigious and well respected organisation.  We are looking forward to seeing how this partnership progresses and the benefits it brings to Orkney farmers.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
