stock.The knowledge and learning gained will influence the future of the Welsh Housing Quality Standard so that all those living in social homes will benefit from reduced energy bills and warmer, more efficient homes.ORP is a key part of the poundm Innovative Housing Programme announced earlier this year, which focuses on building new carbon neutral homes using modern methods of construction, the scheme will contribute to plans to reduce greenhouse gases by  per cent by  with an ambition to reach net zero in future.Applications for the Innovative Housing Programmersquos fourth year are now officially open.A collaboration across Welsh Government, the programme has been part funded through the innovation and business streams.It has long been recognised that retrofitting homes will be a key tool in the green economic recovery, with the ambition the programme will create jobs, provide training and skills in both existing and new retrofit and heating technology.It is hoped technologies and skills created through the programme can be rolled out across wider private sector homes, ensuring Walesrsquo place as lsquofirst mover regionrsquo for decarbonisation of homes by reducing carbon emissions from around , social and fuel poor homes.Ms James said: ldquoThe coronavirus pandemic has highlighted the importance of a warm, secure and affordable home like never before."It has also shown the positive effects of reducing greenhouse gasses.ldquoHousing is responsible for  per cent of all energy consumed in Wales and  per cent of all demand side greenhouse gas emissions.While we have plans in place to ensure new homes are heated and powered only from clean energy sources, ensuring our existing housing stock is as energy efficient as possible is vital towe are to meet our ambitious target of reducing our greenhouse gas emissions by  per cent by .This scheme is essential to tackling climate change, and driving down household energy costs now and in the future.Helping people, including those on lower incomes, to reduce their fuel bills while keeping their homes warm.Economy minister, Ken Skates said: ldquoA welcome boost to the Welsh economy, retrofitting homes will provide quality jobs and training opportunities in the heart of our communities."To help drive forward innovation and build a Welsh supply chain we will be launching a competition for social landlords to apply for research and innovation funding in September.Deputy chief executive and director of policy and external affairs at Community Housing Cymru, Clarissa Corbisiero said: ldquoDespite the immediate threat of covid-, the climate emergency has not gone away, and the pandemic has only highlighted the need for more good quality, affordable homes."Housing associations in Wales are committed to playing their part in tackling these issues."We now have an opportunity to learn from the experiences of the last few months, and be ambitious in our response."This funding is a story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. Drakeford.Indoor visits to care homes will also be allowed from Saturday, August , subject to the strict controls set out in the guidance and conditions remaining favourable.However, the first minister emphasised that theof pupils to schools and colleges from September  is the top priority during this  day regulation cycle.The Welsh Government recognises the value of the events sector to Wales and how cultural, sports and business events are a vital part of the visitor economy and one of the last sectors left to re-open.Initially three small events, with limits of up to  people, and subject to strict risk assessments, will be held across Wales later this month.Outdoor events are being prioritised in this review period, while the weather is mild, due to evidence of lower transmission of coronavirus outdoors.If these small events can be carried out safely, and transmission of the virus remains low, it is hoped the next stage will be increased numbers of participants, allowing a limited number of spectators to attend sporting events and potentially considering trialling small scale business events.In the coming weeks three small scale events will be trialled to inform future review processes.Outdoor events of up to  people include Theatr Clwydrsquos proposals for a number of live outdoor performances from August,  Welsh Triathlonrsquos planned lsquoReturn to Racingrsquo competition at Pembrey Country Park which will be a closed venue and without spectators and a car rally at Anglesey Circuit Trac Mon Race track.The Welsh Government continues to work closely with the UK Government to monitor the outcomes from the trials that have taken place recently.Mr Drakeford also confirmed that from Saturday, August , extended households can expand to include up to four households in an exclusive, extended arrangement.From the same day, weddings and funerals will be able to include a meal for up to  people, in suitably socially distant settings.Subject to the successful resumption of weddings and funerals, it is hoped to further increase the range of indoor ceremonies allowed in the next review period, including christenings, baptisms and bar mitzvahs.Casinos will be allowed to reopen from Saturday, August , provided they follow the guidance available to them.Mr Drakeford said: ldquoWhile coronavirus remains effectively suppressed in Wales and cases continue to fall, the situation in the rest of the UK and further afield is still problematic."Coronavirus has not gone away and so, as we move out of lockdown and look to the future, it is important we do this in a careful and cautious way.ldquoWe appreciate how hard it has been for families not seeing their loved ones and the impact restrictions on visiting care homes is having on peoplersquos emotional, mental and even physical health.ldquoIn an effort to address this we have been working closely with partners and intend to allow indoor visits to care homes to recommence from Saturday, August , subject to the strict controls set out in the guidance and conditions remaining favourable.ldquoIn addition we will trial three small scale events, in partnership with the events organisers, local authorities and other stakeholders, to seethey can be carried out in a safe way, with a view to supporting the sector and making the most of the remaining summer months where we can spend time outdoors.ldquoWe will also learn from pilots being conducted across the UK, in reopening professional sport and indoor theatre to supporters and audiences, so we base our decisions on the best possible evidence available."We will continue to talk with event organisers about the possible resumption of some other activities later in the autumn.ldquoBut, for the time being, we need to learn from how we can safely hold outdoor events while maintaining social distancing.ldquoWe will use the next three weeks to continue to engage with those remaining sectors of our economy that remain affected by coronavirus restrictions."I would like to thank the sector representatives for the way they continue to engage, coming out of lockdown will always be harder than going into it - but, together, we will do it in the safest possible way.From  September, schools and further education colleges willfrom the summer break, and will teach pupils through a iety of ways, either in the classroom or remotely.The First Minister added:ldquoTheof pupils is the most signicant important activity which will take place in Wales during the next  days and most of the headroom we have is being devoted to making this a success.ldquoIt is critical that we get children back into schools in the safest possible way. s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentGAVIN  Stacey was based in Barry after Little Britain star Matt Lucas provided the foot in the door for people unfamiliar with James Corden.That was the situation, location manager Clive Evans, has revealed while he was scouting for places in which the award-winning could be based.And Weston-super-Mare could have masqueraded as lsquoWalesrsquoBarry hadnrsquot won the production companyrsquos heart.Freelance Location manager, Clive Evans, whose projects also include The Bill The Story of Tracey Beaker Doctor Who Very Annie Mary, Young Dracula You Get Me and As If, used Mr Lucas as an ice-breaker as James Corden, in , was relatively unknown and Mr Lucas was featuring in the new series.MORE STORIESGavin and Stacey fans flock to Barry Island to catch sight of the locationsSupporters who helped make Gavin  Stacey happen in BarryThe Gavin and Stacey effect -  years onMr Evans, of Cardigan in West Wales, but now living in Brecon, said: ldquoIrsquod taken a call back in  to check my availability for a small comedy for BBC Three and set in South Wales.ldquoI met up with Christine Gernonand Ruth Jonesat the Castell Mynach pub near Llantrisant one afternoon to discuss the script and the locations they wanted me to scout.ldquoAn hour or so after the meeting, I got the call from the production company Baby Cow offering me the job.ldquoMy first task was to sit with Dave Ferrisand discuss the vision for Gavin  Staceyrsquos backdrop and get a feel for the key locations.ldquoStaceyrsquos hometown was scripted as a South Wales coastal town, but I was given a free run on this so the hunt took me to Aberavon, Porthcawl, Tenby, Saundersfoot, and Weston-super-Mare - a cheatit had been suitable.ldquoBack in  there were a few areas in Barry which were beginning to look a little tired, but it also came with a timeless charm that provided us with the perfect texture and feel that Dave and I had discussed.ldquoAdded to this was the welcome we were given by residents and, in particular, the support of the local council.ldquoPorthcawl was also a serious candidate for the backdrop to this show, but having scouted tirelessly the whole of Barry and Barry Island, I knew that this ticked every box.Mr Evans said Trinity Street was an instant favourite.ldquoI knew Gwenrsquos house was here, he said. ldquoThe terraced houses on a steep hill and its far-reaching views over to Barry Island and docks meant that no matter which direction the camera was pointing, there would be interesting textures and views.ldquoThe next objective was to get inside as many houses as possible to seeany worked for us as Gwenrsquos house.ldquoI letter dropped about  houses to gauge the interest.ldquoIrsquod heard that Matt Lucas was going to be involved so I used his name get to my foot in the door.ldquoThis usually helps.ldquoIn those days very few had heard of James Corden.ldquoI viewed and took pictures of about five houses on that street and Glendarsquos who was one of the first to contact me.ldquoThe decor and character of Glendarsquos house fitted my brief perfectly, but my first thought was that house was a little on the small side.ldquoTo get a film crew and the actors to work in such a tight space would be quite a challenge, butI could convince our director and designer that it could be achieved Gwenrsquos house was found.ldquoI took Dave and Christine along to Trinity Street and both fell in love with the location within minutes.Mr Evans continued: ldquoGlenda was so accommodating.ldquoI remember very well discussing with her the details of how filming on location works, how disruptive the whole process can be and also the location fee.ldquoWhat I do remember was her reaction when I mentioned the amount.ldquoGlendarsquos reply was: ldquoIrsquom so sorry Clive, but I donrsquot think I can cover that.ldquoGlenda thought that she needed to pay for the privilege of having us there and not the other way round.ldquoShe is a lovely lady and still loves being a part of the Gavin  Stacey world.During the locationsrsquo breakdown meeting, we discussed how Pam and Mickrsquos house might look in Billericay so homes were viewed in and around Llandaff and Sully until Dinas Powys was selected thanks to the welcome that was received.ldquoSt Cattwgrsquos Church at Llanmaes was not the first-choice wedding venue for Gavin and Stacey, Mr Evans said. ldquoThey were due to be married at St Nicholas Church at the village of St Nicholas, but a last-minute change of heart by the Church in Wales meant that we needed to find an alternative at the th hour.ldquoA friend and another locations manager called Chris Hill pulled in a favour and we were able to use St Cattwgrsquos.ldquoI dont recall any candidates other than Island Leisure .ldquoWhile filming on the front, Marco opening up early for the crew to be able to get a nice coffee as the weather was pretty unkind.ldquoWe didnt use the interior of the coffee shop as a location in series one, but as it was so cold when we filmed on the seafront the coffees were very welcome.ldquoWe also filmed at the Vale of Glamorgan Resort for the exterior of the wedding fair.ldquoThe interior was shot at the Copthorne Hotel at Culverhouse Cross.ldquoWhile at the Vale resort, the Wales rugby team came into the reception of the hotel.ldquoRuth Jones askedIrsquod be able to set up a photograph of the cast with the Welsh team.ldquoWe got them to agree so out there somewhere are pictures of the Gavin  Stacey cast with the Wales rugby team.ldquoUncle Brynrsquos house was only an exterior in series one so very little was involved in its search.ldquoQuiz night at the Colcot Arms was interesting.ldquoWe were close to completing our filming when the pub opened to the public - so the last few shots took a little while longer than wersquod planned.Mr Evans lives with his we Rhiannon and daughter Cerys Mim and runs his own Film and TV Facilities company.He added: ldquoThe actors usually donrsquot get to see the locations beforehand.ldquoThey are brought to set, run through a quick rehearsal then go for the real thing.ldquoThey then have to go through the whole thing over and over with the camera shooting from dferent angles.ldquoIt is a slow process and  hours on camera gives us around three minutes of footage.ldquoI get a real buzz from seeing locations that I have found on TV, but when it comes to Gavin  Stacey the story I always bring up is that while scouting in the very early days with the series producer in the car he askedI would consider reading for Dave.ldquoMy le could have been so dferent, but I have no regrets as no-one could have played it better than Steffan Rhodri.ldquoMy daughter Cerys Mim was born during filming and James Corden was the first to congratulate me when I ed to work on the show after her birth.ldquoHe joked about us naming her Nessa or Stacey.ldquoBarry and the Vale have always provided me with a fantastic hunting ground for film and TV locations.ldquoIts a huge contributor to South Wales becoming a hotspot for filming in the last decade or so. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey title: lockdown led likely dinosaur footprints discovery penarth beach
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe markings, embedded in a section of rock at the beach, are still being investigated by researchers at NHM, and nothing has been confirmed at this stage.NHM scientists say they do not yet know which dinosaur the prints belong to.On a sunny dayon April , Ms Rees, who had been furloughed from her role as a youth worker at Challenge Wales, came across the site on her morning stroll.Pictures: Kerry ReesShe saidit wasnt for lockdown, she wouldnt have even been in Penarth at the time."Im from Penarth but moved to the Rhondda, and was only in Penarth to look after my mother during the pandemic," she said."I had an idea it could be evidence of a dinosaur. I knew the areahad a history of dinosaur discoveries along this coastline."I didnt have much to do in lockdown and decided to take it further and send them to the NHM. I only started to get excited when they informed me they were very interested in the photos."Im trying to not get too excited yet though, as it is still under investigation - Im not totally sure how it has all come out this morning.Pictures: Patrick Wagstaff"If they turn out to be genuine footprints, then of course its very exciting for the area."If confirmed, they would be the third set of dinosaur tracks in Wales and a huge boost to the areas archaeological heritage, according to researchers.Professor Paul Barrett, Merit Researcher at the NHM, said: "Were pretty convinced that these are dinosaur tracks but are aware there are other geological processes that can create track-like features.Weve just started our work on the site so hope to have a definite answer soon."Kerry found a series of large indentations on the beach - these are deep, round in outline and bear many of the hallmarks of dinosaur tracks, as they seem to be regularly spaced and have raised mud rims like those that form as a foot pushes into wet mud or sand."Dr Susannah Maidment, another researcher working on the project, added: "The rocks that these possible tracks are preserved in date from the Late Triassic period so,were right, theyre among some of the oldest evidence of dinosaurs in the UK."Other trackways of similar age, and one good dinosaur skeleton, have been found a few miles along the coast, near Barry, so south Wales was a busy area for dinosaurs at the time." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. test match appearances he was the most capped Welsh rugby union player until September .He retired from rugby in October .Mr Thomas came out in December .MORE STORIESWales Wide Virtual Pride takes place this weekendCigarette butts Sir David Attenborough portrait unveiled on Barry Island beachShowcase for the brave headlines BarryThe following year he was voted the most influential gay person in the UK in The Independent on Sunday Pink List and received Stonewalls Hero of the Year award.His public confirmation of his sexuality made him the first openly gay professional rugby union player.His autobiography Proud, written with Michael Calvin, won Sports Book of the Year in .Mr Thomas is a tireless supporter and advocate for members of LGBTQ+ communities, and constantly strives to raise awareness, break down barriers and fight the prejudice often faced by the members of these communities.This was never more apparent than when he was the victim of a homophobic attack in , but still requested that the police deal with his attackers via restorative justice, seeking to educate rather than punish.In September , he announced that he was HIV positive with undetectable status meaning that he is not infectious.The following day, he competed in the Ironman Wales event in Tenby, finishing th out of ,, having vowed to "break the stigma" around the illness.For National HIV Testing Week, Mr Thomas also filmed a documentary with Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex and the Terrence Higgins Trust, which aired a few days later on September, .A BBC documentary, Gareth Thomas: HIV and Me, also aired in September .Mr Thomas was honoured in the St Davidrsquos Awards , he was presented an award for his work in raising awareness of the stigma around HIV.The first minister for Wales said he picked Thomas for a special prize as he is a "role model for people of all ages, but particularly young people"."He has been open and honest about his sexuality and his HIV status and his story has "His approach will help break down barriers and stereotypes, increase understanding and will help others in a similar situation to never be ashamed of who they are."Following his diagnosis, Gareth receives regular treatment and counselling from the Department of Sexual Health at Cardf Royal Infirmary and credits the team at the clinic for their care and compassion, helping him through such a who specialises mostly in creating iconic celebrity portraits and lsquoPop Culturersquo imagery with non-traditional mediums such as food .He is a proud patron of Cardf  Vale Health Charity.Mr Wyburn is a great supporter of the NHS and recently, Cardf  Vale Health Charity worked closely with Nathan to share the iconic lsquoNHS Thank You which has been printed onto large scale banners and posters across Cardf and Vale University Health Board sites and adopted by the wider NHS Wales and beyond.Mr Wyburn is a proud gay man with an absolute passion for supporting and championing LBGTQ+ rights, promoting equality, mental health and breaking down barriers for these communities both through his work and his personal le.He was absolutely delighted to be commissioned to create this piece in title: school leaders condemn government reprehensible last minute guidance
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityA ldquorota system limiting the number of students attending secondary schools at any one time could be used in areas with a signicant rise in Covid- cases, according to guidance for England.But while the newguidelines were welcomed by school leaders, one union expressed a ldquoweary, resigned sense of inevitability at the timing.Published by the Department for Educationon Friday evening, it came just before the bank holiday weekend, with millions of pupils ing to class next week for autumn term.All schools will be opening to all pupils for the autumn term.As part of our work to get #BackToSchoolSafely, were helping schools prepare contingency plans as a last resort to maintain consistent education for young people.https:t.co YpzLZXTR pic CuIjUqqTMPmdash Department for EducationAugust , Geoff Barton, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, told BBC Radio rsquos Today programme: ldquoI think, probably, the most polite responsehellip is a weary, resigned sense of inevitability that here we are again, right at the last minute with something that we have been accused of expressing treachery in asking for ndash wherersquos the plan B in case of local lockdown ndash at last it has arrived.Paul Whiteman, general secretary of school leadersrsquo union NAHT, branded the timing of the new guidance ldquoreprehensible.He said: ldquoIt was obvious weeks ago that lockdown advice was necessary.ldquoThe Governmentrsquos decision to publish this at pm on the Friday of the bank holiday weekend before most schools are due tois nothing short of reprehensible and demonstrates a complete lack of regard for the wellbeing of school leaders and their teams.Labourrsquos shadow education secretary Kate Green said that, while the guidelines were ldquolong overdue, the timing of the release of information was ldquounfair to head teachers and school leaders.ldquoSchool leaders have been asking all summer for information about what they should do in the event of local restrictions in their area, she told Sky News.It was obvious weeks ago that such advice was necessary. Publication at pm on the Friday of the Bank Holiday immediately before schools are due tois reprehensible. Contempt for the wellbeing of school leaders. No understanding of the commitment of leaders. @NAHTnews   https:t.co tXLWGBmdash Paul WhitemanAugust , ldquoAnd really unfair, I think, to heads, thatare sent out late on a Friday night, at the start of a bank holiday, days before the first day of the new school term.ldquoHeads are going to feel under a lot of pressure now over this weekend to start looking at these, thinking about how they will implement them in their schools, whether they will have to make any changes to arrangements theyrsquove already put in place.The staggered approach will reduce how many people students come into contact with, helping to break transmission chains by giving enough time at home for symptoms to become apparent, according to the guidance.If an infection is confirmed, schools should contact their local health protection team, who will carry out an assessment to confirm who had been in close contact with the positive case and ask them to quarantine for  days.The announcement was amended shortly after it was published, removing guidance that said entire ldquobubbles, which could be a whole school year, may need to self-isolate.Any suspected coronavirus cases will need to self-isolate and get tested, the guidance adds.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said any changes to school attendance ldquowill only ever be an absolute last resort. vw,vw,px, px"Gavin Williamson He added: ldquoHowever, it is important that both Government and schools prepare for a worst case scenario, so this framework represents the sensible contingency planning any responsible government would put in place.Schools should base their plans on a four-tier system, and the extra measures for secondary schools should kick in at the second tier, according to the guidance.A tier  response will see secondary schools and colleges in a restricted area moving to a rota system, which means pupils will spend two weeks on-site followed by two weeks at home.All schools remain open at tier one, while tiers three and four mean more stringent restrictions such as closures to all but pupils in vulnerable groups or children of key workers..push,i[r].l*new title: contractors make new psm leisure centre covid  ready ahead opening
story: NI shopping centre cafe remains open after staff member tests positive for COVID-Golf Club tournament leads to £, donation to Multiple Sclerosis charityNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPeopleContractors to make new £m leisure centre COVID- ready ahead of openingContractors building the new £m South Lake Leisure Centre in Craigavon are making it COVID- ready ahead of its official opening to the public.By Carmel RobinsonThursday, th August , : pm""Councillors in Armagh, Banbridge and Craigavon involved in project managing the build lavished praise on the contractor during a guided tour this week .A spokesperson for the council said:“Signicant work has been undertaken by the contractor Farrans to bring the build to this stage, and it is anticipated the project completition date will be mid-September.“With construction work on the facility almost complete, Farrans in conjunction with Council are currently installing ultramodern finishing touches that will set this facility apart from others across NI. In today’s current environment health and safety will be of paramount importance on opening, therefore a range of new measures are in place throughout the centre with staff receiving full training in advance of opening.Project Board Members check out the impressive -metre pool at the soon-to-be-opened South Lake Leisure Centre.“The tour showcased everything this expansive facility has to offer including its unique -metre pool, young children’s indoor leisure water feature, a ,m state-of-the-art gym, multiple studios, sensory room, eight-court sports halls, spin studio, soft play area and an on-site café.”As it is sited beside the lakes, the centre has extensive outdoor water sports amenities including windsurfing, water skiing and paddle sports.The centre will open to the public on November .Alderman Kenneth Twyble, Chair of South Lake Leisure Centre Project Board, said: “We were delighted to get on-site to see firsthand the progress of this truly magnicent centre. Everything in the building is of the highest safety and quality standard, leading the way in terms of modern leisure facilities in Northern Ireland. I have no doubt that this centre will be of signicant benefit to our whole community, driving forward our agenda to improve accessibility to leisure services, and act as a catalyst to improve health and wellbeing standards for everyone in our community”. “I know there is great excitement among our residents who are looking forward to the doors of the centre opening on  nd November”.The venue will provide a competitive range of flexible membership and customer schemes allowing easy and affordable access on a one-off or longer term basis, so that everyone can enjoy the new facility in a way that suits their lestyle and budget. title: ni shopping centre cafe remains open after staff member tests positive covid
story: Golf Club tournament leads to £, donation to Multiple Sclerosis charityBarry to be the new Archdeacon in cityNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPeopleNI shopping centre cafe remains open after staff member tests positive for COVID-A popular cafe at a busy NI shopping centre has revealed a member of staff has tested positive for COVID-.By Carmel RobinsonFriday, th August , : pm""Number Seven at Rushmere Shopping Centre in Craigavon said it will remain open.In a statement on their Facebook page, Number Seven said any staff members in close contact with the person who has tested positive for COVID- have been tested and their results came back negative. However those members of staff are now self-isolating.The statement said: “Number Seven Rushmere would like to make everyone aware that one of our members of staff tested positive for Covid . Rushmere Shopping Centre in Craigavon. Photo courtesy of Google.“They last worked at Number Seven on Saturday where they had limited customer contact, felt unwell on Monday evening and got tested on Tuesday afternoon.“Any staff members that were in close contact with this person have been tested and those results have been negative and they are now self isolating.”The cafe said that they are following the Public Health Agency guidelines and advice. welcomed by DUP and SFArmagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council’s event to celebrate the th anniversary of VJ Day has been welcomed by both the DUP and Sinn Fein.By The NewsroomThursday, th August , : pm""Council has confirmed a shared history event to mark the occasion will take place this Saturday, August .Many local people were heldas Japanese prisoners of war and the stories of their experience still haunt the families to this day.The event will include a lecture from renowned historian Dr Eamon Phoenix, poetry reading by local historian Richard Edgar and a musical accompaniment from piper Ian Burrows.Speaking about the event, Council’s Lord Mayor, Councillor Kevin Savage said: “Shared history events are important for a ided society.“We hope that by embracing social media and digital technology we can attract wider audiences comprised of people who – for ious reasons – might not normally attend such an event in person.“With COVID- still very much a concern at the moment, we are hoping to run more online events like these to ensure we’re minimising the risk to our residents while still offering the excellent events we’re known for, albeit in a slightly dferent way.”DUP group whip Councillor Darryn Causby said it was important for Council to mark the occasion, widely regarded as the end of the second World War.“It is important for Council to mark this occasion,” he said.“We are obviously disappointed that it could not be marked in a more substantial way than what we are doing.“However, we welcome the fact all parties recognise the vital role the British Army played during the second World War and we welcome that across the piece.”Speaking about ABC Council’s shared history event SinnFein group leader, Councillor Liam Mackle said: “Many local people lost their lives in this conflict.“The Lord Mayor will pay special tribute to local man Jim Haughey. Jim fought against fascismin the International Brigade in the Spanish Civil War and was later killed in .“Council officers deserve special praise for organising this event which was inclusive and contributed to our shared understanding of history.”Initially proposed by DUP group leader, Councillor Mark Baxter duringthe course of July’s full council meeting, the idea to hold a socially distanced event compliant with COVID regulations was put to a vote following a fiery debate.In total,  members voted for the proposal with the DUP, UUP, Alliance Party and IndependentCouncillorPaul Berry in support of the proposal.The five SDLP members present abstained and the nine Sinn Fein members present voted against the proposal.The event will be broadcast on Council’s facebook page from -.am on Saturday, August . title: peter cardwell lifts lid life spad westminsters corridors power
story: Ballylisk showroom extensionContractors to make new £m leisure centre COVID- ready ahead of openingNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPoliticsPeter Cardwell lts lid on le as a ‘SPAD’ in Westminster’s corridors of powerIt’s a far cry from Peter Cardwell’s homestead of Richhill but hisnew book promises to lt the lid on the corridors of power at Westminster.By Carmel RobinsonFriday, th August , : am""Having been a Special Advisor to four Cabinet Ministers in four departments, Peter gained a keen insight in the inner workings of government.Now, in his tell-all book called ‘The Secret Le of Special Advisers’, Peter gives the public a unique insight into le within the corridors of power.Peter, the son of Ken and Sandra Cardwell, said: “The book is based on my three-and-a-half-year stint supporting the UK government as a special adviserto four Cabinet Ministers in four departments. Peter Cardwell at Hillsborough Castle.“I hope the book is a fun, frank and honest account of what it’s like to work in Westminster.”It’s his first time as an author and already his book has set tongues wagging across social media.Special advisers are a part of the government, yet who they are and what they do is much misunderstood. Key advisers to Cabinet ministers and the Prime Minister since the s, their role is shrouded in mystery, despite acres of newsprint devoted to high-profile members of the cohort, such as Alastair Campbell and Dominic Cummings.Peter Cardwell’s book lts the lid on the people Piers Morgan called ‘these miserable little creatures’, revealing who spads are, how Cabinet ministers use and interact with them, how much influence they have and how they deal with the civil service. Featuring numerous anecdotes from dealing with counter-terror emergencies in COBRA to explaining what a dental dam is to the Justice Secretary, to having your inside leg measured in a Minister of the Crown’s office, this book has it all.BBC Political Editor Laura Kuenssberg said: “Peter allows you to peep behind the curtain of a much caricatured but little understood part of our political universe. With the structures of government in flux it’s a timely look at how some of the key relationships in Westminster work, and how they sometimes misfire.”Michael Crick, veteran political journalist and investigative authorsaid: “A book we have long needed.Peter Cardwell’s book fizzes with stories and humour from his experience as an adviser to four dferent ministers, and his years as a Westminster journalist with BBC Newsnight, ITV and Sky News.”https:www.portadowntimes news uk-news ni-man-peter-cardwell-loses-job-boris-johnson-reshuffle-A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: esteemed principal of st caireall s ps set to retire
story: When Mairead McHugh was a pupil of St Cairealls Primary School, Aghyaran, she never envisaged that she would one day become principal.However, she would go on to do just that, and she was the first ever past pupil to take up the role!And now, after a prolic career spanning  years at the popular primary on the Trienamongan Road, near Castlederg, she will hang up her teaching hat.Mrs McHugh, who ed to St Cairealls in September  as a young teacher and later progressed to principal, has strived tirelessly over the years to enhance the profile and educational offerings of the school.Reflecting on her career, Mrs McHugh said: I suppose one of the highlights over the past quarter of a century is the exceptionally strong community link there has been between St. Cairealls PS and the community within the parish of Aghyaran.We have had many, many events within the school campus, including rural craft displays, sheep shearing exhibition, dog trials, combine harvester visiting the school, pantomimes, concerts, historical trips and trips to farms to name a few.Another highlight was the close working partnership between St Cairealls and our local football club, St Davogs GFC. Over my years as principal, we have had great support from the club and some of our past pupils have gone on to represent their county.For me, the notable achievement has been to see the way in which past pupils have progressed in a iety of chosen careers and been successful in so many walks of le.Another achievement is the way in which the staff both past and present have worked together as a team to have accomplished so many things over the past  years, not least to have been awarded Outstanding in our last inspection report.The development of the St. Cairealls Community Playschool on the school site has also brought me great joy over the past ten years to see it now as a successful pre-school provider with DENI status and funding for our local children.Having spent so many years of my le in St Cairealls P.S., it has become a second home and the staff and pupils a second family. Retiring for me brings mixed emotions. However , I am looking forward to having more time to spend with my family, my husband Kevin, our daughters Emer, Niamh and Fionnuala and their partners. Also our son Michael and his partner and my two precious grandsons Micheal and Braidan. Mrs McHugh concluded: I want to offer good wishes to the future of this very special school – St. Cairealls Primary School, Aghyaran and success and happiness to my successor, Mrs Michelle Ellis. title: post primary pupils now to wear face coverings in corridors
story: Education Minister Peter Weir has announced that guidance on face coverings will be updated to include wearing them in corridors of post-primary schools. This will come into effect on  August when schoolson a full-time basis. The Minister said: “My key priority is that pupilsto school on a full-time basis, as soon as it is safe to do so. “Following further advice which I have received today from the Chief Medical Officer and the Chief Scientic Adviser, I am recommending that pupils and teachers wear a face covering in corridors and other communal areas of post-primary schools from next week when schoolsfull-time. This updates the existing guidance on the use of face coverings in educational settings. “The current public health advice is that the use of face coverings provides some benefits, however, it is not a replacement for frequent hand washing, social distancing where possible, covering your mouth and nose when you cough or sneeze and regular cleaning of surfaces. It is also important to remember that evidence suggests that the risk of transmission in schools is relatively low compared to some other settings. “My existing guidance on the reopening of schools already deals with the use of face coverings. In terms of school transport, the advice remains the same, that we strongly recommend that all pupils wear a face covering on all dedicated school transport including buses and taxis where it is appropriate for them to do so. “In relation to communal areas in schools, the guidance already strongly encourages face coverings for activities that entail large numbers of staff or pupils within an enclosed space where social distancing is not possible. “Given the risk mitigations in place in schools to limit and contain the spread of Covid-, face coverings are not recommended as being compulsory for routine use in education settings. However, staff and pupils may wish to use them during the routine school day and this is acceptable. Schools should also be aware that some personsare exempt from wearing face coverings. “I will continue to keep all guidance in respect of education settings under review in light of the latest medical and scientic advice. Peter Weir said: “The first step in keeping our schools safe is that anyone with symptoms should not attend school. Parents should not send their children to schoolthey have any of the Covid- symptoms including: a high temperature a new, continuous cough a loss or change to your sense of smell or taste.” The Department’s New School Day Guidance will be updated to reflect this recommendation.  addthis, Leave your commentTyrone Constitution- High Street, OmaghBT BDTel:     , ,, , ,  .jsp, , ,   , ,success:
